attributes.title: The Burden of Proof: Barriers to Women in Party Controlled Candidate Selection

q1.value: The Burden of Proof: Barriers to Women in Party Controlled Candidate Selection

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: There remains limited understanding of the challenges women politicians face when navigating entry into politics in the world’s newest democracies. Much of the existing scholarship draws on women’s political experiences in countries with formal candidate selection processes, whether voter-controlled systems such as the United States or party-based mechanisms as in most of Western Europe. However, this can result in biased inferences about why relatively few women decide to run for political office and even fewer are successful in making it onto the ballot. The reality for candidates in most new democracies is that they are not selected through formal primary processes. Instead, parties in countries that transitioned to multiparty politics through the Third Wave still tend to select candidates for office through opaque selection processes. In this context of informal party-controlled candidate selection, I study the preferences of party selectorates, the strategies women employ when entering politics, and the barriers they face in securing a party’s nomination. Here I present a pre-analysis plan for the survey experimental component of this project. The survey will be conducted on randomly selected party members and aspirants from the 2016 election in Zambia. It will explore how party selectorates evaluate women aspirants and whether the preferences of party officials systematically vary at different levels of the party. Moreover, it will investigate whether aspirants believe these preferences exist. By experimentally varying gender along with important attributes such as a candidate’s financial and organizational capacity, the survey will establish whether or not the burden of proof falls on women candidates in party- controlled candidate selection systems that makes running for office difficult and costly.

q16.value: H1: Women candidates are less likely to be selected than male candidates. H2: Women candidates are asked to meet higher qualifications than male candidates. H3: Women candidates are more likely to be selected than equally qualified male candidates if they have greater financial resources. H4: Women candidates are less likely to be selected than equally qualified male candidates if they do not display independent control of their financial resources. H5: Women candidates are less likely to be selected than equally qualified male candidates if they do not visibly display their financial resources. H6: Local party members are more likely to prioritize financial resources when evaluating candidates compared to national party members H7: Women candidates are more likely to be selected than equally qualified male candidates if they have greater organizational capacities. H8: Women candidates are less likely to be selected than equally qualified male candidates if they do not visibly display their organizational resources. H9: Women candidates are less likely to be selected than equally qualified male candidates if they do not display independent control of their organizational capacities. H10: National party members are more likely to prioritize organizational capacities when evaluating candidates compared to local party members

q17.value: The surveys are being conducted on tablets by Zambian enumerators throughout the country from June to December 2019. Enumerators will be sent to each of the ten provinces with an estimated sample of 2,000 party members and 900 aspirants. The surveys ask participants questions to gauge political experience, candidate preferences, measures of ambivalent sexism, and financial expectations during the multiple phases of candidate selection. Experimentally, the surveys employ two different designs to assess my hypotheses. The first asks participants for recommendations on how candidates could improve their chances in the 2021 election. The gender of the theoretical candidates will be randomized. The survey asks participants to recommend what groups the candidates should belong to, how much money they should have for the elections, what assets they need to own, and what experience they need to have.

q27.value: Local Enumerators: Beverly Schicilenge, Grace Kyungupengu, Christopher Lubasi, Kalonde Siulapwa, Edgar Miyanda, and Kawide Nakasamu

attributes.title: Islamic Party Incumbency and Religious Conflict in Indonesia

q1.value: Islamic Party Incumbency and Religious Conflict in Indonesia

q2.value: Nicholas Kuipers | Michael Weaver | Gareth Nellis

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The object of this study is to investigate whether local incumbency by religious—and specifically Islamic and Islamist political parties—affects the incidence and severity of religious violence.

q17.value: Natural experiment; close-elections regression discontinuity design.

registration_responses.q1: Islamic Party Incumbency and Religious Conflict in Indonesia
registration_responses.q2: Nicholas Kuipers | Michael Weaver | Gareth Nellis
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: The object of this study is to investigate whether local incumbency by religious—and specifically Islamic and Islamist political parties—affects the incidence and severity of religious violence.
registration_responses.q17: Natural experiment; close-elections regression discontinuity design.

q2.value: Jennifer McCoy | Abigail Bowen | Clark DeMas | Daniel Lanford

q5.value: We thank Georgia State University and the Provost Faculty Research Fellowship for funding this research., We appreciate the helpful advice from Kirk Hawkins, Levi Levente, Bruno Castahno, Ryan Carlin, and Cengiz Erisen.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The larger study aims to analyze the causes and consequences of political polarization. In this particular study, we examine the role of emotions such as resentment and gratitude in producing or mitigating attitudes reflecting political tribalism, populism, and erosion of democratic norms. Further, we investigate how political rhetoric interacts with emotions to activate these political attitudes of tribalism, populism, and support for erosion of democratic norms. Theory of relative deprivation: predicts emotion of resentment at a perceived inequity, injury or injustice. A Politics of resentment highlights the sense of lack of fairness, when the out-group receives more than they deserve and the in-group receives less than they deserve. Antidote to resentment is gratitude in psychology of emotions literature. We posit that the equivalent feeling of gratitude in the politics of resentment would be solidarity – a sense of collective accompaniment and well-being, or communal cooperation. Based on the theories above, we intend to prime resentment and gratitude through our experimental treatments. Priming resentment should exacerbate (while gratitude will lessen) negative political attitudes and support for illiberalism. We will also examine the moderating effect of political rhetoric on emotions, and its independent effect on the dependent variables.

q16.value: 1. Perceptions of unfairness produce negative emotions that activate populist attitudes/behavior, racial resentment (U.S.), political tribalism and support for democratic erosion relative to control. 2. Perceptions of being helped produces positive emotions that deactivate/decrease populist attitudes, racial resentment (U.S.), political tribalism and support for democratic erosion relative to control (and to Relative Deprivation) 3. Political rhetoric about unfairness can activate DVs directly, or indirectly by positively moderating impact of feelings of relative deprivation on populist attitudes, racial resentment (U.S.) ,political tribalism and democratic erosion. 4. Political rhetoric about helpfulness can deactivate DVs directly, or indirectly by counteracting (negatively moderating) impact of feelings of relative deprivation on populist attitudes, racial resentment (U.S.),political tribalism and democratic erosion.

q17.value: We will use factor analyses to create proper measures for the outcome variables, such as populism, political tribalism, racial resentment, and support for democratic norms. We will first confirm that the Unfair and Helped treatments prime the expected emotions (as indicated in a prior pilot analysis with a student sample). We will then compare each of the emotion treatments with the control group to determine the impact on the dependent variables. The second phase of the analysis will examine the moderating effect of the rhetoric treatments on the dependent variables, as well as its independent effect on the dependent variables. The 3x3 design allows us to test each of these combinations of treatments and controls.

q18.value: The first iteration of this experiment will happen in the U.S.; however, we may run the experiment again in other nations.

q27.value: The experimental treatments are text based and will be displayed in an experimental survey hosted by Qualtrics.

attributes.title: Intergovernmental Organization (IGO) Endorsements and Support for Syrian Refugee Resettlement

q1.value: Intergovernmental Organization (IGO) Endorsements and Support for Syrian Refugee Resettlement

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study presents respondents with a mock newspaper article and asks them to indicate their support for increasing the number of Syrian refugees admitted for resettlement to the United States. In the study I shall be asking the respondents to indicate their level of support for the proposed increase in refugee admissions while undertaking the following manipulations: 1. Whether the respondent is told that other countries (specifically, Canada and Germany) have done so; 2. Whether the respondent is told that prominent IGOs, NGOs, or leaders of multinational corporations support the initiative; and 3. The number of refugees that the other countries have committed to resettle.

q16.value: Hypotheses: The hypotheses being tested are as follows: H1: Providing information about other countries’ willingness to accept Syrian refugees will cause US respondents to become more supportive of the proposal. H2: When respondents are told that other countries are making a smaller commitment to resettling Syrian refugees than the US, their support for the proposal will decline. H3: Providing information about endorsements by the OECD or World Bank, but not the UN, will cause respondents to become more supportive of the proposal. H4: Providing information about endorsements by the leaders of major corporations will cause respondents to become more supportive of the proposal. H5a: Providing information about endorsements by IGOs will cause left-leaning respondents to become more supportive of the proposal, but will have the opposite effect on right-leaning respondents. H5b: Providing information about endorsements by the leaders of major corporations will cause a larger increase in support for the proposal among right-leaning than left-leaning respondents. H6: Providing information about the success of other countries’ policies in the context of their status as fellow members of IGOs will lead to an increase in support for the program that is even greater than the effect of either stimulus in isolation.

attributes.title: How family experience shapes xenophobic attitudes: Evidence from forced relocation

q1.value: How family experience shapes xenophobic attitudes: Evidence from forced relocation

q5.value: We thank Jens Hainmueller, Robin Harding, David Laitin, Gabe Lenz and members of the Immigration Policy Lab at Stanford for helpful comments on this design.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: How does emigration or forced relocation, experienced in the past by an individual’s ancestors or her hometown, affect her present-day attitudes towards immigrants and asylum seekers? Xenophobic sentiment is on the rise in many western countries receiving large immigrant and refugee inflows, and there is increasing agreement that such sentiment seems to be motivated more by cultural than by economic factors. And yet, the demographic profile of the “rooted” native population in both the US and Europe has itself to a large extent been shaped by immigration or forced relocation in the 20th century or earlier. How does this historical experience of forced relocation affect modern-day views of refugees from Syria? Our project attempts to answer this question in the context of Greece, a country that serves as an entry port to Europe for a large number of refugees today —with almost 400,000 new asylum seekers arriving in the country between May 2015 and September 2015 (UNHCR 2016)— and whose present-day population composition was also significantly determined by a population exchange in the early 20th century. In 1923, after the defeat of the Greek army in the Greco-Turkish war of 1919–1922, Greece and the newly formed Republic of Turkey signed an international treaty agreeing to a compulsory exchange of populations. The exchange was carried out on the basis of religion, with approximately 1.5 million Orthodox Christians expelled from the regions of Asia Minor and Pontus in Turkey and 500.000 Muslims expelled from Northern Greece. The inflow of refugees from Turkey amounted to almost 25% of Greece’s then population of 5 millions. Newly settled refugees faced adverse economic and social conditions in the first years of their settlement in Greece, and were often treated with mistrust and outright discrimination by the natives. Today, 80 years later, and after a successful settlement effort undertaken by the Greek government with international assistance, the third generation of refugees from Turkey is fully integrated and indistinguishable from native Greeks, both in terms of observable characteristics and of their perception among the larger population. We ask whether individuals from refugee families or those living in historical refugee settlements have more or less tolerant attitudes towards Syrian refugees, and how those attitudes respond to the salience of the historical experience of forced relocation.

q16.value: The main competing hypotheses that explain the reaction of descendants of forced migrants towards refugees today are perspective taking and inter-group competition. The salience of past forced relocation may increase the capacity to empathize with refugees if people with similar experiences in their family are able to draw parallels between their plight and that of another group. At the same time, recent research has documented the role of in-group victimization in shaping out-group attitudes. This body of research has shown that members of a victimized in-group associate themselves with attitudes of deservingness and entitlement and the in–group’s victimhood is portrayed as unique, exclusive and incomparable. Reference to in-group victimhood—in this case the forced displacement from Turkey to Greece—can thus lead to victimhood competition and in turn boost prejudice again Syrian refugees even if in-group and out-group are not in direct conflict with each other. We are interested in the average effect of the salience of past forced relocation on attitudes and behaviors towards refugees. We would interpret a positive effect as evidence of perspective taking and a negative one as support for group competition and competitive victimhood. We hypothesize that these average effects are stronger for a) individuals living in localities with a stronger presence of Asia Minor forced migrants and their descendants, and b) those living closer to camps where refugees from Syria are housed today.

q17.value: We will conduct a phone survey in a sample of 2000 people in the north of Greece, where the vast majority of Asia Minor refugees was settled in the 1920s. We will randomly prime a subset with a reference to the historical event of forced relocation to Greece from Turkey. We will then collect attitudinal and quasi-behavioral measures of support for Syrian and other Asian refugees. We will compare the responses of descendants of Asia Minor refugees (whom we will identify through a series of demographic questions at the end of the survey) to those of other Greeks. We will then examine heterogeneity patterns by share of Asia Minor refugees (as per the 1928 Greek census) in a respondent's township and by distance to the nearest refugee camp.

q27.value: Public Opinion and Market Research Unit of the University of Macedonia

attributes.title: The Political Economy of Ethnicity in Africa: A Research Design

q1.value: The Political Economy of Ethnicity in Africa: A Research Design

q2.value: Yannick I. Pengl | Philip Roessler | Valeria Rueda

q5.value: This research is supported by a National Science Foundation grant, award #1628498. We thank Layla Abi-Falah, Sidhart Bhushan, Hedda Roberts, Aaron Spitler, and Henry Young for excellent research assistance., Earlier versions of this research design were presented at WGAPE, LSE, March 2018; the Annual Meeting of the American Political Science Association, Boston, September 2018; , Princeton University Comparative Politics Colloquium, October 2018; and the Annual Meeting of the African Economic History Network, Bologna, October 2018. We are grateful to participants for their suggestions and feedback.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: What are the origins of the ethno-political landscapes that shape contemporary states? A voluminous and influential literature points to the impact ethnicity — social identity based principally on shared descent — has on politics and the allocation of state resources. From social trust to provision of public services to civil war and genocide, ethnicity is found to powerfully structure a wide-range of political and economic processes. Understanding the factors that shaped these ethno-political divisions is an important line of inquiry in the study of political science and development economics. Until recently, there were few systematic studies into the origins of ethnic diversity. Over the last few years, however, a burgeoning literature has emerged on this subject. Ethnic fractionalization has been linked to variability in physical geography; migratory distance from the cradle of humankind and duration of human settlements; the effects of the slave trades; and a history of political centralization, or state antiquity. Less well understood is what causes the politicization of ethnicity, that is, why, among the socially-relevant ethnic groups in a given country, some groups or coalitions of groups are politically-active but not others. This represents a major gap in the literature. A growing body of research finds that, following from Posner (2004a, 854), important economic and political outcomes are best modeled focusing on “the groups that are actually doing the competing over policy” – that is, among the politically- relevant ethnic groups – rather than among “ones that an ethnographer happens to identify as representing distinct cultural units.” But without knowing the sources of the ethno-political configurations that structure politics this literature is vulnerable to serious selection problems. Most fundamentally, the factors causing group formation and politicization may also affect economic outcomes, obscuring the true effect of ethnic politics. Our study will address this gap in the literature and analyze the historical sources of Africa’s ethno-political landscape.

q16.value: What are the origins of the ethnic landscapes that define contemporary states? In Africa, we argue the current ethnno-political configurations were shaped by the dual economic revolutions that swept across the continent in the 19th and 20th centuries: the spread of cash crop agriculture and the diffusion of printing and writing technologies. We propose that these economic changes transformed ethnicity via their effects on politicization and boundary-making. The adoption of print technologies is hypothesized to have increased groups’ communication capabilities, while leading to more salient—yet porous—ethnic identities through an Andersonian process of imagined communities. Cash crop endowments are also hypothesized to have increased the salience of ethnicity and groups’ mobilizational capabilities due to the occupation of a common economic niche and greater resource wealth, but with less porous boundaries due to a Weberian process of social closure. More specifically, we hypothesize that groups endowed with cash crops or print technologies during the colonial era are likely to be more politically-relevant in the post- independence period and their members are expected to have more salient ethnic identities, more homogeneous political preferences, and lower levels of trust and marriage with other ethnic groups. As a secondary hypothesis, we will test whether cash crops and printing caused differential effects on ethnic boundary-making and conflict. The commercialization of agriculture is hypothesized to have increased economic competition and social closure, leading to a legacy of less porous ethnic boundaries and more communal conflict. We expect the printing press had the opposite effect, contributing to more open ethnic boundaries and reducing the risk of ethnic conflict.

q17.value: To test the effect of these economic processes on ethnic politicization, we combine detailed historical data on cash crop production and the record of nearly all historical publications in African languages with contemporary ethnicity data. Following from Roessler et al. (2019), historical cash crop data is drawn from Hance, Kotschar and Peterec (1961). It identifies 9,517 geocoded production points valued at $289,270 per point, covering 9 groups of cash crops, 20 minerals and metals, and forest, animal and manufactured products. Publications data represents a novel dataset compiled from Rowling and Wilson (1923) and Mann and Sanders (1994). Together, these two sources cover approximately 10,000 titles in 370 distinct languages. To capture ethnic politicization, we employ group-level and individual-level measures. At the group-level, we use the Ethnic Power Relations (EPR) dataset (Vogt et al., 2015), which indicates the ethnic groups or coalitions that are competing for access to state power. To measure ethnic politicization at the individual level, we use survey data from Afrobarometer and the Demographic and Health Surveys that reflects expressed ethnic salience, inter-ethnic marriage and inter-ethnic trust, and the homogeneity of political preferences. To test potential heterogeneous effects of cash crops and print technologies on the openness of boundary-making, we will compare the relative effect sizes of the two economic variables on the social processes of inter-ethnic marriage and inter-ethnic trust. We also expect there to be different effects on local ethnic conflict. The exclusionary nature of ethnic boundaries brought about by cash crops, combined with heightened competition for land, should increase the relative risk of ethnic conflict compared to the inclusionary boundaries induced by the printing press. In our empirical models, our primary unit of analysis will be a given ethnic group identified in the Ethnologue database. Ethnologue aims to capture the complete universe of ethno-languages regardless of their social or political relevance, demographic size, or contemporary use (Simons and Fennig, 2017). Each ethnolinguistic group is uniquely identified with a given isocode and for the subsample of groups for which it is possible, they are also mapped. Additional data sources can thus be merged either spatially (using each group’s location), or with the ethnic name. We will spatially match the historical cash crop data, as well as geographic characteristics that serve as controls. Using ethnolinguistic names, we match the publications data and the outcome measures of ethnic politicization and boundary-making. With the final dataset, we will then compare relative levels of the outcomes between groups treated by cash crops, groups treated by print technologies, groups treated by both, and “control groups” that were not treated by either economic change. Following from Nunn and Wantchekon (2011), information on historical ethnic homelands and survey respondents’ stated identities allows to separate ethnic ”stayers” from ethnic ”migrants”, to distinguish location-specific effects from culturally transmitted traits that travel with those who move. Our empirical strategy faces identification challenges and we propose several strategies to overcome them in our full pre-analysis plan.

registration_responses.q1: The Political Economy of Ethnicity in Africa: A Research Design
registration_responses.q2: Yannick I. Pengl | Philip Roessler | Valeria Rueda
registration_responses.q5: This research is supported by a National Science Foundation grant, award #1628498. We thank Layla Abi-Falah, Sidhart Bhushan, Hedda Roberts, Aaron Spitler, and Henry Young for excellent research assistance., Earlier versions of this research design were presented at WGAPE, LSE, March 2018; the Annual Meeting of the American Political Science Association, Boston, September 2018; , Princeton University Comparative Politics Colloquium, October 2018; and the Annual Meeting of the African Economic History Network, Bologna, October 2018. We are grateful to participants for their suggestions and feedback.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: What are the origins of the ethno-political landscapes that shape contemporary states? A voluminous and influential literature points to the impact ethnicity — social identity based principally on shared descent — has on politics and the allocation of state resources. From social trust to provision of public services to civil war and genocide, ethnicity is found to powerfully structure a wide-range of political and economic processes. Understanding the factors that shaped these ethno-political divisions is an important line of inquiry in the study of political science and development economics. Until recently, there were few systematic studies into the origins of ethnic diversity. Over the last few years, however, a burgeoning literature has emerged on this subject. Ethnic fractionalization has been linked to variability in physical geography; migratory distance from the cradle of humankind and duration of human settlements; the effects of the slave trades; and a history of political centralization, or state antiquity. Less well understood is what causes the politicization of ethnicity, that is, why, among the socially-relevant ethnic groups in a given country, some groups or coalitions of groups are politically-active but not others. This represents a major gap in the literature. A growing body of research finds that, following from Posner (2004a, 854), important economic and political outcomes are best modeled focusing on “the groups that are actually doing the competing over policy” – that is, among the politically- relevant ethnic groups – rather than among “ones that an ethnographer happens to identify as representing distinct cultural units.” But without knowing the sources of the ethno-political configurations that structure politics this literature is vulnerable to serious selection problems. Most fundamentally, the factors causing group formation and politicization may also affect economic outcomes, obscuring the true effect of ethnic politics. Our study will address this gap in the literature and analyze the historical sources of Africa’s ethno-political landscape.
registration_responses.q16: What are the origins of the ethnic landscapes that define contemporary states? In Africa, we argue the current ethnno-political configurations were shaped by the dual economic revolutions that swept across the continent in the 19th and 20th centuries: the spread of cash crop agriculture and the diffusion of printing and writing technologies. We propose that these economic changes transformed ethnicity via their effects on politicization and boundary-making. The adoption of print technologies is hypothesized to have increased groups’ communication capabilities, while leading to more salient—yet porous—ethnic identities through an Andersonian process of imagined communities. Cash crop endowments are also hypothesized to have increased the salience of ethnicity and groups’ mobilizational capabilities due to the occupation of a common economic niche and greater resource wealth, but with less porous boundaries due to a Weberian process of social closure. More specifically, we hypothesize that groups endowed with cash crops or print technologies during the colonial era are likely to be more politically-relevant in the post- independence period and their members are expected to have more salient ethnic identities, more homogeneous political preferences, and lower levels of trust and marriage with other ethnic groups. As a secondary hypothesis, we will test whether cash crops and printing caused differential effects on ethnic boundary-making and conflict. The commercialization of agriculture is hypothesized to have increased economic competition and social closure, leading to a legacy of less porous ethnic boundaries and more communal conflict. We expect the printing press had the opposite effect, contributing to more open ethnic boundaries and reducing the risk of ethnic conflict.
registration_responses.q17: To test the effect of these economic processes on ethnic politicization, we combine detailed historical data on cash crop production and the record of nearly all historical publications in African languages with contemporary ethnicity data. Following from Roessler et al. (2019), historical cash crop data is drawn from Hance, Kotschar and Peterec (1961). It identifies 9,517 geocoded production points valued at $289,270 per point, covering 9 groups of cash crops, 20 minerals and metals, and forest, animal and manufactured products. Publications data represents a novel dataset compiled from Rowling and Wilson (1923) and Mann and Sanders (1994). Together, these two sources cover approximately 10,000 titles in 370 distinct languages. To capture ethnic politicization, we employ group-level and individual-level measures. At the group-level, we use the Ethnic Power Relations (EPR) dataset (Vogt et al., 2015), which indicates the ethnic groups or coalitions that are competing for access to state power. To measure ethnic politicization at the individual level, we use survey data from Afrobarometer and the Demographic and Health Surveys that reflects expressed ethnic salience, inter-ethnic marriage and inter-ethnic trust, and the homogeneity of political preferences. To test potential heterogeneous effects of cash crops and print technologies on the openness of boundary-making, we will compare the relative effect sizes of the two economic variables on the social processes of inter-ethnic marriage and inter-ethnic trust. We also expect there to be different effects on local ethnic conflict. The exclusionary nature of ethnic boundaries brought about by cash crops, combined with heightened competition for land, should increase the relative risk of ethnic conflict compared to the inclusionary boundaries induced by the printing press. In our empirical models, our primary unit of analysis will be a given ethnic group identified in the Ethnologue database. Ethnologue aims to capture the complete universe of ethno-languages regardless of their social or political relevance, demographic size, or contemporary use (Simons and Fennig, 2017). Each ethnolinguistic group is uniquely identified with a given isocode and for the subsample of groups for which it is possible, they are also mapped. Additional data sources can thus be merged either spatially (using each group’s location), or with the ethnic name. We will spatially match the historical cash crop data, as well as geographic characteristics that serve as controls. Using ethnolinguistic names, we match the publications data and the outcome measures of ethnic politicization and boundary-making. With the final dataset, we will then compare relative levels of the outcomes between groups treated by cash crops, groups treated by print technologies, groups treated by both, and “control groups” that were not treated by either economic change. Following from Nunn and Wantchekon (2011), information on historical ethnic homelands and survey respondents’ stated identities allows to separate ethnic ”stayers” from ethnic ”migrants”, to distinguish location-specific effects from culturally transmitted traits that travel with those who move. Our empirical strategy faces identification challenges and we propose several strategies to overcome them in our full pre-analysis plan.
registration_responses.q18: Angola, Benin, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Republic of the Congo, Côte d’Ivoire, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Djibouti, Equatorial Guinea, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Gabon, Ghana, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mali, Mauritania, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Rwanda, São Tomé and Príncipe, Senegal, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan, Tanzania, The Gambia, Togo, Uganda, Zambia, Zimbabwe
registration_responses.q19: Our main unit of analysis is the Ethnologue group. Among the 38 countries in our dataset, there are 1998 linguistic groups and 3205 dialect groups. For our individual and couples-level analysis using Afrobarometer and DHS, we have in the ballpark of 150,

attributes.title: When Governments Make Dreams Come True: The Political Effects of Public Housing

q1.value: When Governments Make Dreams Come True: The Political Effects of Public Housing

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: How do voters form their attitudes towards incumbents? What shape voters' attitudes towards redistribution and the state? In this study, we examine the repercussions of a large, visible, and programmatic housing policy on social and political attitudes. We expect that voters' attitudes towards incumbents and regarding social issues to change at different paces: we argue that the expectation of becoming a policy beneficiary shapes political attitudes, while the actuality of becoming a policy beneficiary affects social beliefs and political attitudes. We use the lotteries implemented in the city of Rio de Janeiro to allocate housing units to compare lottery winners and nonwinners' opinions on incumbents, political parties, state vs. market, redistribution, and the program's impact on beneficiaries' welfare. We survey lottery participants after they have won the lottery but before they have moved to their homes (late lottery) and participants that have already moved to their home for at least two years (early lottery). We also examine this program's impact on social welfare using administrative data.

q16.value: We are examining four main hypotheses. First, we expect that lottery winners will have a higher evaluation of incumbents than lottery nonwinners even before winners move to their new home. Second, and related to that, we expect that lottery winners will show higher support for the president and the city government (not the state government). We expect that voters will credit politicians more closely related to the creation and implementation of the program. This is an important caveat given the current political instability and recent changes in the presidency in Brazil. Third, we expect lottery winners to have higher evaluations of the incumbents after they move to their new homes, but this support should decline with time. Fourth, we expect lottery winners to develop more pro-market and less pro-state attitudes after they move to their new homes, but we do not expect such changes before they move to their new homes.We based this hypothesis and all of our related predictions on previous work done by Di Tella, Galliani and Schargrodsky (2007) and de Janvry, Gonzalez-Navarro and Sadoulet (2014). Although we favor this interpretation, our subjects are receiving a good from a governmental program that is clearly labeled as such (based on our fieldwork). Thus, their preferences towards the state may not change at all (because of the cross-pressures from becoming a de facto homeowner and a government beneficiary) or they may even move in the opposite direction, and develop more pro-state preferences. We break down these four general hypotheses into several predictions which we list in our pre-analysis plan. We also expect heterogeneous treatment effects on participants' welfare based on the location of the housing projects (relative to downtown) and on political opinions based whether or not they receive other governmental benefits (such as Bolsa Família).

q17.value: We will conduct two surveys (early and late lotteries) and an analysis of administrative data using a list of all lottery participants (winners and nonwinners) that we compiled using public data from the city's housing agency. The lotteries are conducted by the state-run bank (Caixa Econômica Federal) in a partnership with city housing agency (Secretaria Municipal de Habitação e Cidadania) and the housing program is largely funded by the federal government. The analysis of the surveys and the administrative data will include weights to account for the different probabilities of winning the lottery (treatment assignment), which vary by lottery and over time. Our main estimation strategies will be based on intent-to-treat effects and we anticipate a sizable noncompliance rate.

q19.value: 2,000 late lottery participants, 4,600 early lottery participants, maximum of 736,733 subjects (all lottery participants) for administrative data (depends on outcome analyzed)

q23.value: This research has been deemed exempt from IRB review by the Human Subjects Committee.

q27.value: Ministérios das Cidades, Secretaria Municipal de Habitação e Cidadania (RJ), Caixa Econômica Federal

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: We theorize that business interests - both at the constituency level and elected officials' personal financial interests - affect public policy making. We conduct a survey with a list experiment assessing the sensitive question as to whether elected officials make policy decisions with their personal business interests in mind. We also conduct a survey experiment examining the relationship between business interests and elected officials' decisions to remove racially intolerant symbols.

q16.value: We conduct a 9-question survey. In the list experiment, we randomize a 4-item and 5-item list to respondents. See questions Q1a and Q1b in the attached pre-analysis plan. In the survey experiment, we have a control condition and two treatment conditions. In the control condition, elected official respondents answer how likely they are to vote to remove the Confederate flag with no vignette. In one treatment, elected officials are asked to consider a business moving away from their district and then asked the same question about how likely they are to vote to remove the Confederate flag. In a 2nd treatment, elected officials are asked to consider a business in which they own stock moving away from their district and then post-treatment asking the same question about how likely they are to vote to remove the Confederate. Additional conditional hypotheses regarding elected official party, race, and business background are also tested (see the pre-analysis plan for details). These questions and the hypotheses, measures, and quantities of interest are laid out in the pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: Difference of means tests; and OLS.

attributes.title: Military Enrollment, the Welfare State, and Free Trade in America

q1.value: Military Enrollment, the Welfare State, and Free Trade in America

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Scholars have long argued that international trade creates both winners and losers within each country. In order to maintain public support for free trade, governments therefore must provide re-distributive policies that help compensate the losers. For example, governments often provide unemployment benefits and job re-training subsidies to workers who lose their jobs due to trade. Ehrlich and Hearn (2014) find experimental support for this "compensation hypothesis" - less-educated survey respondents report greater support for free trade when they receive priming information about the welfare benefits available to trade losers through the U.S. Trade Adjustment Assistance program. In ongoing research, I demonstrate that trade-related job losses lead to local increases in U.S. Army enrollment. This project makes contributions to two related debates in international political economy - who is hurt by international trade, and how does the government respond? In terms of identifying trade losers, it joins Autor, Dorn, and Hanson (2013, 2016) in arguing for a broader understanding of the local impacts of trade. While several studies have documented the job losses and wage reductions caused by import penetration, the literature still tends to focus on adults that were active in the labor market before trade shocks. By focusing on U.S. Army enrollment - a career choice made predominately by recent high school graduates - this paper establishes the important impact that trade has on young workers first entering the labor market in the midst of trade shocks. In terms of understanding government responses to "trade losers," this paper demonstrates the need to look beyond the welfare state policies documented by previous studies. Extant scholarship assumes that government policy responses are driven by efforts to "compensate" losers and increase public support for free trade. In contrast, the link between trade-related job losses and Army enrollment is driven by a very different causal logic. The Department of Defense increases enrollment in trade-impacted counties as an efficient strategy for recruiting an all-volunteer military, not as part of government efforts to increase public support for free trade. In short, this paper suggests that the political economy literature underestimates the negative impact of free trade and overlooks government policy responses that few would consider part of the traditional welfare state.

q16.value: With this link between trade-related job losses and U.S. Army enrollment in mind, this survey experiment explores whether or not Americans view military enrollment as a form of welfare compensation. As explained above, scholars of the "compensation hypothesis" predict that government welfare spending increases public support for free trade. Will knowledge of the trade-military connection increase support for free trade? If survey respondents view increased military enrollment as a negative consequence of trade, then being primed with information about the trade-military relationship should decrease support for free trade. However, if survey respondents view military enrollment as a welfare program that compensates "trade losers," then being primed with information about the trade-military relationship should increase support for free trade. In general, we expect highly-educated respondents and respondents that identify as Democrats to view increased military enrollment as a negative consequence of free trade. Therefore, when these respondents are primed with information about the trade-military relationship, they will decrease their support for free trade. In contrast, we expect less-educated respondents and respondents that identify as Republicans to view military enrollment as a form of welfare program that compensates trade losers. Therefore, when these respondents are primed with information about the trade-military relationship, they may increase their support for free trade.

q17.value: Subjects will be exposed to one of three primes, and then asked about their views regarding international trade policy. One prime will provide information about the U.S. government's Trade Adjustment Assistance program, two primes will provide information regarding U.S. military recruitment, and one prime will serve as a control. We will then estimate a linear model of subjects' trade policy preferences, accounting for their treatment condition, their party ID, education level, party ID and education level interacted with their assigned condition, and a vector of standard control variables

q23.value: IRB Application Under Review at George Washington University

attributes.title: Tax morale: a cross-country experimental study

q1.value: Tax morale: a cross-country experimental study

q2.value: Jon Mellon | Tiago Peixoto | Lily Tsai | Johannes Hemker

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan lays out a study of tax morale in a cross-country online survey experiment. To summarize, we will expose subjects to one of three conditions: a “participation” condition in which subjects are asked to state their expenditure preferences, an “accountability” condition in which subjects are informed about efforts to punish the abuse of government money, and a control condition. We will then study whether and how these interventions affect a survey measures of tax morale, as well as respondent’s beliefs about what the fine for tax cheats would be.

q16.value: Overall Pooling across countries, tax morale (Q4) and the desired level of fines for tax cheaters (Q5) are higher in the participation condition than in the control condition Pooling across countries, tax morale (Q4) and the desired level of fines for tax cheaters (Q5) are higher in the accountability condition than in the control condition Pooling across countries, in the participation condition, a larger fraction of respondents respond yes to the manipulation check question Q7 than in the control condition Pooling across countries, in the accountability condition, a larger fraction of respondents correctly respond to the manipulation check question Q6 than the control condition Additional hypotheses: In the accountability condition, a larger fraction of respondents should respond yes to Q7 than in the control condition Potential mechanism 1 : In the accountability and participation conditions, larger fractions of respondents respond yes to Q8 than in the control condition Potential mechanism 2: In the accountability condition, respondents will be less likely to state that abuse of money is common in Q9 Heterogeneous treatment effects: We expect the effects of the accountability intervention to be higher for “outsider” groups like women and private sector employees, and lower for business owners and public sector employees Cross-country variation We do not have strong priors about the distribution of treatment effects across countries, and we will explore these descriptively once the data are in. We intend in particular to look for variation on the following dimensions: language, presence of democratic institutions, state capacity, economic development and cultural identity. We will also compare the effect magnitudes on the outcome variable to those on the manipulation checks.

q18.value: Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, Venezuela, United States, Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Russia, Slovakia, Spain, Sweden, Algeria, Angola, Kenya, Morocco, Nigeria, South Africa, Tunisia, Uganda, Australia, Bangladesh, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Kazakhstan, Malaysia, Pakistan, Philippines, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam, Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Turkey
